Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel Grant for RTSS'17 Ph.D. Student Poster Forum on Real-Time Aspects of Internet of Things and Cyber-Physical Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
IEEE Real-Time Systems Symposium (RTSS) is the premier conference in the area of real time systems, presenting innovations in the field with respect to theory and practice. RTSS provides a forum for the presentation of high-quality, original research covering all aspects of real-time systems theory, design, analysis, implementation, evaluation, and experiences. RTSS 2017 will continue making RTSS an expansive and inclusive symposium, looking to embrace new and emerging areas of real-time systems research.

This proposal is to organize, in conjunction with the symposium, a Ph.D. student poster forum (i) to discuss the set of interdisciplinary research problems that arise in the context of IoT and CPS, (ii) to determine commonalities and fundamental differences between the IoT and CPS domains, (iii) to identify novel applications that become feasible due to the integration of local vs. hosted computing, local vs. hosted storage, communication, and interaction with the physical world at scale, and (iv) to define an initial system architecture that addresses some of these research problems. The primary goal is to help students (and the real-time community) recognize that IoT and CPS systems are different from each other as well as historically over-engineered real-time embedded systems of the past, and to provide a forum by which students can discuss their proposal for addressing the complicated aggregate systems issues that arise in this context.

Forums of this sort have significant educational value for graduate students. It encourages the students to begin seriously thinking about their personal future research agenda and opens pathways to burgeoning ideas. There is a plan to reward best submissions as well as encourage students with financial difficulties to participate, both merit-based and need-based stipends will be provided to offset participation costs. The project includes broadening participation criteria as part of the recruitment strategy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this work is to promote student participation at
RTSS, the flagship real-time systems conference. In particular, both
merit-based and need-based stipends are provided to offset
participation costs.

Students were supported for their travel expenses to RTSS'17 and RTSS'18, the flagship real-time systems conference.

The real-time community has been instrumental in developing the field
of CPS and has pioneered sensor network systems, which can be regarded
as the predecessors of IoT devices. RTSS is the flagship conference
and the world’s premier conference on real-time systems. The symposium
traditionally brings together researchers in the broad field of
embedded and real-time computing, control, and communication. RTSS
2017 and 2018 have a special focus
on both IoT and CPS. This activity promoted further
education of the community and of the IoT and CPS themes as an important research
avenue, particularly for the real-time community. It is imperative that
real-time aspects be considered as IoT and CPS systems may be subject
to catastrophic failures in the absence to considering timing
constraints. The proposed activity seeks to educate and train students to
this effect. The community will be asked to critique the work of
the students and to advise them on their Ph.D. prospective with a
focus on training and motivating the next generation of researchers.

The activity has significant educational
value. Papers/posters/demonstration proposals were solicited and
reviewed by a program committee that selected the top submissions for
presentation. To reward best submissions as well as encourage students
with financial difficulties to participate, both merit-based and
need-based stipends were provided to offset participation costs.

This project contributes to human resource development by educating
students through research, providing feedback to them, plus giving
students the communication and writing skills needed to advance
science and engineering for future generations.
